coredata.dc:description: AbstractWe discuss the contribution of proton photoproduction interactions in the isotropic infrared/optical background to the cosmic neutrino fluxes. This contribution has a strong dependence on the proton injection energy spectrum, and is essential at high redshifts. head.ce:title: Neutrino production by UHECR proton interactions in the infrared background

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We discuss the contribution of proton photoproduction interactions in the isotropic infrared/optical background to the cosmic neutrino fluxes. This contribution has a strong dependence on the proton injection energy spectrum, and is essential at high redshifts. It is thus closely correlated with the cosmological evolution of the ultra-high energy proton sources and of the infrared background itself. These interactions may also contribute to the source fluxes of neutrinos if the proton sources are located in regions of high infrared emission and magnetic fields.

ce:sections.ce:para: The assumption that the Ultra-High Energy Cosmic Rays (UHECR) are nuclei (presumably protons) accelerated in luminous extragalactic sources provides a natural connection between these particles and ultra high energy neutrinos. This was first realized by Berezinsky and ZatsepinÂ [1] soon after the introduction of the GZK effectÂ [2]. The next full calculation of the generated neutrino flux was published by SteckerÂ [3] in 1973. The problem has been revisited many times after the paper of Hill and SchrammÂ [4] who used the non-detection of such neutrinos to limit the cosmological evolution of the sources of UHECR.

These so-called cosmogenic neutrinos are produced in photoproduction interactions of the UHECR with the ambient photon fields, mostly with the microwave background radiation (MBR). The GZK effect is the limit on the highest energy a cosmic ray proton can retain in propagation through the MBR. It sets a cutoff in the cosmic ray energy spectrum in case UHECR sources are isotropically and homogeneously distributed in the Universe. The physics of these photoproduction interactions is very well known. Although the energy of the interacting protons is very high, the center of mass energy is low, mostly at the photoproduction threshold. The interaction cross section is studied at accelerators and is very well known. Because of the steep cosmic ray spectrum most of the interactions happen at threshold, at the Î+ resonance, where the cross section reaches 500Â Î¼b. The mean free path in MBR reaches a minimum of 3.4 megaparsecs (Mpc) at proton energy of 6Ã1020Â eV. The average energy loss of 1020 protons is about 20% per interaction and slowly increases with the proton (and center of mass) energy.

The fluxes of cosmogenic neutrinos are, however, very uncertain because of the lack of certainty in the astrophysical input. The main parameters that define the magnitude and the spectral shape of the cosmogenic neutrino fluxes are: the total UHECR source luminosity LCR, the shape of the UHECR injection spectrum (Î±CR in case of power law spectrum), the maximum UHECR energy at acceleration Emax and the cosmological evolution of the UHECR sources. These are the same parameters that Waxman and BahcallÂ [5] used to set a limit on the neutrino fluxes generated in optically thin sources of UHECR.

The microwave background is not the only universal photon field that has to be taken in consideration. Especially interesting is the isotropic infrared and optical background (IRB). The number density of IRB is smaller than that of MBR by more that two orders of magnitude. On the other hand, protons of lower energy can interact on the IRB, and the smaller number density has to be weighted with the higher flux of interacting protons. The present Universe is optically thin to 1019Â eV and lower energy protons, but even at low redshifts the proton interaction rate quickly increases. This is different from the interactions on MBR, where the interacting protons quickly lose their energy even at z=0. The cosmological evolution of UHECR injection is thus of major importance for the contribution of such interactions to the flux of cosmogenic neutrinos.

We use the IRB model of Franceschini et al.Â [6] shown in Fig.Â 1 together with the MBR in terms of energy density. The model consists of two components: âstarâ, near infrared, which covers the higher photon energies, and âdustâ, far infrared that continues down to MBR. The total IRB number density is significantly smaller than that of MBR. The model yields 1.6 photons/cm3, a factor of 250 less than the MBR. The IRB is measured directly after subtraction of point sources and is also estimated from the absorption of TeV photons coming from extragalactic sourcesÂ [7]. Such estimates affect mostly the near infrared part of the spectrum. Photons of wavelength above 40Â Î¼m affect only the Î³-ray fluxes above 10Â TeVÂ [8] where the statistics is usually low and the flux decrease could also be due to absorption in the Î³-ray sources.

In addition to the lower total photon density the IRB covers much wider wavelength range than the microwave background, and its photon density per unit energy is even smaller. The interactions of UHECR on IRB photons are indeed very rare in the present universe. Fig.Â 2 shows the fraction of the proton energy that is converted to neutrinos as a function of the proton energy in propagation on a distance of 200Â Mpc.

In the derivation of the neutrino limit Waxman and Bahcall use cosmic ray source emissivity LCR=4.5Â±1.5Ã1044Â ergMpcâ3yrâ1 between 1019 and 1021Â eV for power law cosmic ray energy spectrum with Î±=2. The assumption is that no cosmic rays are accelerated above 1021Â eV. The cosmological evolution of the source emissivity is assumed to be (1+z)3 to z=1.9 then flat to z=2.7 with an exponential decay at larger redshifts. We will first this input to find the contribution of proton interactions on the IRB.

The local neutrino flux of flavor i, Fi(EÎ½i) generated from the propagation of cosmic ray protons over cosmological distances is calculated as an integral over redshift and over the source proton energyÂ Eps (1)c4ÏEÎ½iâ«â«Lz,EpsYEps,EÎ½i,zdEspEspdz with zmax=8 and Emin=1018/(1+z)Â eV (1019Â eV when MBR is the only target) and Emax=1022Â eV with a exponential cutoff at 1021.5Â eV. The neutrino yields are properly scaled with redshift and the resulting neutrinos are redshifted after production (seeÂ [11] for a full description of the procedure). The emissivity LCR is used to calculated the injection flux normalization at 1019Â eV. The term âstandard emissivityâ means that we use the W andÂ B normalization of the flux at this energy. In case the injection spectra are steeper than Eâ2 the true emissivity above 1019Â eV is smaller.

The resulting Î½Î¼+Î½ÌÎ¼ spectrum from interactions in the IRB photon field of Fig.Â 1 for a cosmological model with Î©Î=0.7, Î©M=0.3 and H0=75Â kmsâ1Mpcâ1 is shown with a dotted line in Fig.Â 3. The flux peaks at 1016.3Â eV at 2.5Ã10â18 Â cmâ2sâ1srâ1. The peak is at energy lower than the peak of the MBR interactions (shown with a dash-dot line) by a factor of 20, and its magnitude is also lower by a factor ofÂ 10. Next, we show in the same figure with a dashed line the contribution of IRB for a scenario in which the injection spectral index is changed to Î±=2.5 and all other parameters are the same. There is a noticeable shift of the peak position to still lower energy. The peak is now located at 1015.7Â eV and is higher by a factor of aboutÂ 7. The contribution of IRB is now smaller than that of MBR (Î±=2) only by about 30%. The highest curve in Fig.Â 3 shows the IRB contribution for Î±=2.5 and cosmological evolution with n=4 and then constant to z=10 followed by an exponential decrease. The location of the peak does not change but its magnitude increases by almost a factor of three. It is now 50% higher than the âstandardâ MBR generated cosmogenic neutrinos. It is obviously not correct to compare fluxes obtained with different assumptions for the cosmological evolution and we do it only to have a feeling for the magnitude of the neutrino fluxes. The Î±=2.5 spectra decrease the flux of cosmogenic neutrinos of energy above 1019Â eV.

Both the spectral shape and the cosmological evolution of the UHECR sources affect the contribution of the IRB to the cosmogenic neutrino flux. The most important factor, however, is the shape of the injection spectrum. It is worth to note that the maximum proton energy at acceleration does not affect the IRB generated fluxes, since they are due mostly to protons of energy below 1020Â eV, as can be observed in Fig.Â 2.

At energy about 3Ã1018Â eV the cosmogenic neutrino fluxes of Î½Î¼+Î½ÌÎ¼ are very close to the limit for source neutrinos. The reason is simpleâin propagation from large distances protons lose almost all of their energy in interactions on MBR. An interesting feature is the flux of Î½Ìe (not shown), which peaks at energy about 3Ã1015Â eV. The origin of this flux is neutron decay, and a small Î½Ìe flux is generated in neutron interactions on MBR.

The n=3 cosmological evolution of the sources increases the fluxes by about a factor of five compared to a no-evolution scenario. The increase is not energy independentÂ [11]. The highest energy neutrinos are generated at small redshifts. The low energy neutrinos come from high redshifts because of two reasons: the threshold energy of protons for photoproduction interaction decreases, and the generated neutrinos are further redshifted to the current epoch. The âstandardâ flux (Î±=2.0, n=3) would generate about 0.4 neutrino induced showers per km3yr in the IceCubeÂ [14] neutrino detector and 0.9 events with energy above 1019Â eV in the Auger [15] observatory (for target mass of 30Â km3 of water) assuming that at arrival at Earth the flavor ratio Î½e:Î½Î¼:Î½Ï is 1:1:1 because of neutrino oscillations. The rate in EUSOÂ [16] in not affected by interactions in the IRB since the detection threshold is of order 1020Â eV. Shower events come from: NC interactions of all neutrinos, CC interactions of Î½e, the hadronic (yEÎ½) part of the CC interactions of muon and tau neutrinos and from Ï decay. Although very prominent, the Glashow resonance does not produce high rate of events because of its narrow width. Ice Cube should also detect very energetic muons with a comparable rate which is difficult to predict without detailed detector simulations.

Changing the proton injection spectrum to a power law with Î±=2.5 moves the maximum of the cosmogenic neutrino flux to lower energy and increases the contribution of the interactions on IRB. At the same time the flux of higher energy cosmogenic neutrinos decreases. The shower event rates in IceCube and Auger become 0.44 and 0.31, respectively.

Assuming a stronger source evolution, (1+z)4, makes a big difference in the expected fluxes. AÂ power law source spectrum with Î±=2.5 it generates 1.2 events in IceCube and 0.66 events in Auger. The cosmogenic neutrino spectrum for Î½Î¼+Î½ÌÎ¼ is shown with full squares in Fig.Â 4. The contribution of interactions on MBR is shown with a solid line.

The biggest uncertainty in these results, which is not listed above, is the cosmological evolution of the infrared/optical background. The estimates above assume that it is the same as of MBR, i.e., that the IRB was fully developed at z=8, which is the limit of the redshift integration. This does not seem to be a realistic assumption, although models of the IRB emissionÂ [17] predict very strong evolution of the far infrared emission, especially between redshifts of 10 toÂ 100.

The maximum proton energy at acceleration Emax is unknown, but having in mind the highest energy Fly's Eye shower of 3Ã1020Â eV one should expect that astrophysical sources accelerate protons at least to 1021Â eV. The injection spectrum is also not very well determined since the result of proton propagation depends on the UHECR source distribution. Attempts to derive the injection spectrum in the case of isotropic homogeneous source distribution end up with injection spectra not flatter than Eâ2.4 power lawÂ [18,19]. The extreme case is developed by Berezinsky et al.Â [20] who derive Î±=2.7 injection spectrum in case of no cosmological evolution.

The total luminosity required for the explanation of the observed events at 1019 eV grows with the spectral index, and in the case of Berezinsky et al. becomes (3â4)Ã1046Â ergMpcâ3yrâ1 for evolutionary model with Î±=2.45 or non-evolutionary models with Î±=2.70. Note that the steep injection spectra apply only to cosmic rays of energy above 1018Â eV and that the injection spectrum should flatten at lower energies. Otherwise after propagation the extragalactic protons would dominate the cosmic ray flux at 1017 eVÂ [20] which is contrary to observations. This may suggest that the highest flux in Fig.Â 4 may have an exaggerated low energy extension.
Generally, steep spectra generate only a small event rate for neutrinos above 1019Â eV and enhance the IRB contribution.

Expressed in terms of (1+z)n the cosmological evolution of different astrophysical objects is observed to be between n=3 andÂ 4. AÂ strong evolution with n=4, as used above, may be too optimistic, but not entirely out of range. As seen from Fig.Â 4, a strong cosmological evolution does not only increase the total flux, but also moves the peak of the cosmogenic neutrino spectrum to somewhat lower energy.

Finally, the cosmic ray source emissivity, which was normalized to the flux of UHECR at 1019 by WaxmanÂ [12] could easily be higher or lower by half an order of magnitude. One can then assume a pessimistic IceCube shower event rate of 0.1 event per km3yr and an optimistic rate of 4â5 events.

It is obvious that a detailed calculation of the flux of cosmogenic neutrinos should include the interactions on the infrared background. We plan to do that with better models of the cosmological evolution of IRB and of UHECR sources and describe the calculation in more detail in a forthcoming paper. One should also keep in mind that if the UHECR sources are located in regions of high infrared and optical photon density, the fluxes of source neutrinos could increase. The effect may be much stronger if 1019 eV and lower energy protons are contained in the region by high magnetic fields.
